title: Oakland Teachers Strike Ends With Tentative Contract Deal
summary: District says teachers will receive salary increase and one-time bonus. OAKLAND, Calif.-Teachers in Oakland ended their weeklong strike Friday after agreeing to a tentative contract.

title: Trump and the Revolt of the 'Somewheres'
summary: The new nationalism appeals to those who feel left out by the rise of 'declarative government' by judges and bureaucrats.. Trumpism has an essence, and that essence is nationalism. It is bigger than President Trump and certain to outlast his tenure in office.

title: Crazy Elon vs. the SEC, Round Two

He seems intent on blowing a big hole in the agency's credibility when it comes to enforcing public company disclosure rules.

title: William Neely Escaped His Union, But It Wasn't Easy
summary: The Janus ruling was supposed to liberate government employees. Check the fine print.. William Neely, a state hospital psychiatric aide in Berks County, Pa., had long been frustrated with his union. He felt the leaders of his local American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees affiliate were looking out for their own interests, not his. After the U.S. Supreme Court ruled last year in Janus v. Afscme that government workers could no longer be forced to pay so-called agency fees as a condition of employment, Mr. Neely thought he saw his chance to resign his membership without paying a penalty. Not quite.

summary: His company, Las Vegas Sands Corp., says the casino magnate is feeling side effects from medication he is taking for the treatment of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. summary: With a vibrant national economy, why is New York still pleading for an Amazon location?. Amazon's February decision to abandon a planned expansion in New York City underlined the hostile business climate in the Empire State. A new campaign to beg the Internet giant to reconsider suggests New York is in worse shape than advertised. Amid an historic abundance of American jobs, why would the country's largest market need a campaign to create them?

title: AP Exams Are Honest, Broadly Based Tests
summary: Courses like AP calculus, based on national standards, force students to rise up, improve their logical reasoning skills and compete on a national playing field.. After reading "AP Tests Are Still One of the Great American Equalizers" (Review, Feb. 23), I realized that the arguments against Advanced Placement exams haven't changed much in the 45 years I have been teaching AP physics: teaching to the test, absence of creative autonomy and undue pressure.

title: I Inherited Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder
summary: The impact of genocide cannot possibly end with the surviving victims. The magnitude of the horror will have lasting effects for many generations.. Regarding Susan Pinker's "Mind & Matter: Inheriting the Trauma of Genocide" (Review, Feb. 23), in which she reviews a recent study that found PTSD symptoms in the adult children of surviving Tutsis of the Rwanda genocide: The devastating intergenerational effects of trauma are seen in the children of refugees as well. My colleagues Drs. Sheila Gahagan and Wael Al-Delaimy and I conducted a similar study in which we interviewed 200 Somali refugee mothers and their 10-year-old children currently living in San Diego. The mothers had experienced significant trauma and some torture in refugee camps or in the Somali civil war. Interestingly, most of the mothers gave birth to their children in the U.S., thus the children weren't directly exposed to trauma.

title: Too Much Academic Science Is Bad Science
summary: Steve Milloy recounts that bad science and sequelae of the Tulane University report in Science of hormone disrupters. Multiple labs couldn't replicate the finding.. Steve Milloy recounts the bad science and sequela of the Tulane University report in Science magazine of hormone disrupting chemicals in many paper receipts. Multiple labs couldn't replicate the finding ("Bad Science May Banish Paper Receipts," op-ed, Feb. 26). At the time, I wrote to the Tulane researchers asking for the data. No go. I asked those who funded the research. Again, no go. The experiment consisted of looking at pairs of compounds. With many pairs and experimental variability, the most extreme result looked real and was reported.

title: It's Time to Stand Up to Those Strident Progressive Art Bullies
summary: If Western culture is to survive, we need to put an end to demanding modern-day sensitivity in art and literature from past eras.. Regarding Edward Rothstein's "Art Review: History Through an Ideological Filter-An overview of American art politicizes the past, offering demolition over deconstruction" (Life & Arts, Feb. 14): It won't be long before progressives demand the actual destruction of paintings because of their alleged retroactive insensitivity instead of the mock destruction depicted in Valerie Hegarty's 2007 "Fallen Bierstadt," an ideological mockery of Albert Bierstadt's "Bridal Veil Falls, Yosemite."

summary: January's drop is the first monthly decline since 2015. Income softened in January, driven by a sharp dive in dividend payouts that reverted an outsize jump in December income.

title: The Police Are the Solution to Church Stonewalling on Sexual Abuse
summary: Why are these investigations not in the hands of the police, FBI and the courts?. Regarding Tim Busch's "Everyday Catholics Can Fight Sex Abuse" (Houses of Worship, Feb. 22): Any explanation of why sexual abuse of children by the Roman Catholic clergy, or any member of the clergy, should fall into the realm of the church for investigation and punishment totally escapes reason. This abuse has far-reaching consequences for those children. Why are these investigations not in the hands of the police, FBI and the courts? Aren't these crimes against children, not just religious infractions?

title: Would You Pay $32,709 for a Lab-Grown Diamond?
summary: Serious designers are making lab-grown gems-produced without the human and environmental tolls of traditional mined diamonds-desirable. WHETHER YOU'RE BUYING "ethically harvested" honey made by local beekeepers or wallets stitched in a family-owned factory in Portugal, so-called "conscious shopping" has become almost unbearably trendy. Some purchases, however, do merit the term. With their less-than-wholesome mining history (often involving human and environmental tolls), diamonds were ripe for a virtuous makeover. Companies producing lab-grown diamonds with renewable energy have popped up globally, touting the gems' ability to dazzle without harm.

title: The Vietnam War's Legacy in Art
summary: A new exhibition features reflection and protest in response to the national tragedy. In 1966, Jesse Treviño was drafted out of art school and sent to Vietnam. In a Smithsonian oral-history interview, he recalls thinking that he might die amid sniper fire and explosions, while imagining all the things he still wanted to paint. Mr. Treviño survived, but his right hand-the one he used to paint-was injured so badly that surgeons couldn't save it. Slowly and despite great pain, he reinvented himself as an artist. Between 1971 and 1973 he painted "Mi Vida" ("My Life"), a large-scale panorama that features the face of a female schoolmate who died young, the artist's own Purple Heart medal, his hand prosthesis and a self-portrait in shades of gray.

title: U.S. Dollar Advances Against Canadian Currency

title: A Regime Still Fighting the 'Great Satan'
summary: Since the Iranian Revolution of 1979, the Islamic Republic's foreign policy has been defined by one key principle: anti-Americanism.. Four men dressed in camouflage uniforms jumped out, grabbed me, threw me face-down into the back seat and sped away. I knew immediately that they were Iranian security agents. Screaming at me in Farsi, they drove wildly to Evin Prison, where they informed me I was accused of being a spy.

title: Millennials Are the Therapy Generation
summary: People in their 20s and 30s seek mental-health help more often, and they are changing the nature of treatment. Kristina, a 27-year-old publicist living in Manhattan, has been in and out of therapy since she was 9, when her parents got divorced. Back then, she says, "I had a pretty pragmatic view of what was happening, and so did my parents-going to therapy was just something you make kids of divorce do." During her first year of college, Kristina (who requested that only her first name be used) suffered a sexual assault. Again, she says, therapy afterward was a given. "I figured I would use therapy to get through my trauma and then be done," she says. "I eventually learned that's not really how it works." She has had four or five different therapists since then. So have most of her friends.

title: How to Make the Hot Job Market Work for You
summary: Is now the time to change jobs, push for that raise or lobby for a new assignment?. The job market a decade ago was in such free fall that multiple generations are still feeling the scars of lost income and thwarted career opportunities. By contrast, the demand for workers now is so hot, it's easy for many job seekers--especially those with sought-after tech skills--to feel almost giddy.

title: 'Clara Barton's Civil War' and 'Louisa on the Front Lines' Review: Conquering New Territory
summary: Nursing was not an organized profession in America until the Civil War created an urgent need for people to care for wounded soldiers. Many women answered the call, including Clara Barton and Louisa May Alcott.. In 1834, Sarah Josepha Hale, the great American editor and champion of female education, published an article in her magazine calling for the nursing profession-then the domain of men-to be opened to women. While all women ought to be educated in "the important art of attending the sick," it said, nursing was especially suitable employment for widows, spinsters and other women who were forced by circumstances to earn a living.

title: 'El Norte' and 'América' Review: The Improbable Empire
summary: Spain's hold on its New World territories was remarkably weak, depending on the goodwill of local elites to enforce its decrees. How did it remain in power for centuries?. Juan Evans, the last great Spanish explorer of the Americas, raised the royal banner over a Mandan settlement on the Upper Missouri in September 1796. His orders were to befriend those natives, frustrate the unholy alliance between the British and the fledgling United States, promote commerce and pioneer a new route across the continent. But Evans had an ulterior, personal motive. He was a newly naturalized Spaniard, one who hardly spoke Spanish but was fluent in his native Welsh-part of a sodality of nationalists who aimed to pry Wales from the British crown, or, failing that, to found a new Wales in America.

title: 'Nature's Mutiny' Review: Tracking History's Turbulence

In 1683, thick ice on London's River Thames bore coaches, sled races, shopping stalls and a few brothels.

title: 'Skeleton Keys' Review: How to Grow a Spine
summary: An adult human body contains at least 206 bones. Human hands are more dexterous than those of great apes, our shoulders better for throwing. But our ice-age forebears had stouter skeletons than we do, thanks to their strenuous lifestyles.. Pity poor Richard , who snatched defeat from the jaws of victory and met a most grisly end. Even though his army outnumbered that of Henry Tudor at the Battle of Bosworth Field, he led a reckless cavalry charge in the hope of personally finishing off the future Henry VII. Unfortunately, his white courser got stuck in the mud, and he found himself surrounded by a swarm of formidably armed Welshmen.

title: 'The Wall' Review: We Shall Defend Our Island
summary: Fear, exhaustion, boredom, cold: Such is the lot of a soldier guarding the perimeter of a postapocalyptic Britain.. In the best dystopian novels, the worst has already happened. Whether the nightmare is Orwell's Big Brother, Huxley's human hatcheries or the myriad variations on nuclear annihilation and worldwide contagion, a dreaded new reality has dawned. Entering it, we are set adrift in a hallucinatory aftermath, feeling mildly delirious and increasingly anxious. As well we should.

title: Fiction: Faith and Family, Midwestern-Style
summary: A tender novel about religious belief is also a reflection on aging and loss.. In books as in life, grandparents usually belong to the supporting cast, adored but cheerfully taken for granted. Yet a complex relationship lies behind the Hallmark card patronization. Grandparents feel the same unconditional love for their grandchildren as for their own kids, but in most cases it comes without control or final responsibility-a powerlessness that can be freeing but can also, in times of difficulty, be a special kind of torment.

title: Mysteries: The Fly Girl and the Valedictorian
summary: Out on a date, Princeton-bound valedictorian Titus Crespo winds up involved in an incident that leaves a man dead-and Titus the captive of gun-wielding thugs.. Titus 'Crisp' Crespo, the 19-year-old Brooklyn youth at the center of Karen Ellis's existential thriller "Last Night" (Mulholland, 313 pages, $27), is "a brown-skinned, fro-headed hybrid of a young man" and a Princeton-bound senior-class valedictorian. But when an argument with a hostile cop leads to a night in jail, causing Crisp to miss his graduation, he makes a series of poor choices that shunt him into a violent environment.

title: Children's Books: Love and War as the Meddling Gods Look On
summary: Set in the early 20th century but narrated by the Olympian gods, Julie Berry's novel for young adults is wonderfully romantic and inventive story from start to finish.. Some narrators are omniscient, some are unreliable and some, as we're reminded in "Lovely War" (Viking, 468 pages, $18.99), are divine. Julie Berry's phenomenal novel opens in a stylish Manhattan hotel room in 1942, with a cuckolded man confronting his wife and her lover. It is a sordid if not unheard-of situation, perhaps, but in this case the love triangle has been formed on Mount Olympus. Though clad in the fashions of the time, the unfaithful wife is Aphrodite, the goddess of love; her handsome paramour is Ares, the god of war; and the outraged husband who has snared the cheating pair in a powerful golden mesh is crook-backed Hephaestus, god of the forge.

title: 'L.E.L.' Review: The Case of the 'Female Byron'
summary: The wild life and scandalous death of Letitia Elizabeth Landon (1802-38), a celebrity-author notorious in her time and nearly forgotten today.. In her first book, "The Brontë Myth" (2001), Lucasta Miller retrieved the three scribbling sisters, Charlotte, Emily and Anne, from more than 150 years of variously fabricated identities and liberated their writings from the clutch of myth. The work was not only a brilliant exercise in reclamation but also an exploration of shifts in cultural temper and a shrewd meditation on biographical writing. "L.E.L.: The Lost Life and Scandalous Death of Letitia Elizabeth Landon, the Celebrated 'Female Byron' " is only Ms. Miller's second book, but it too is a valiant recovery job-the life of a writer, a woman first celebrated, then notorious, in her time and nearly forgotten today.

title: Remembering Pat Conroy: Southern Comforter
summary: Three new works-a memoir, an oral history and an anthology of essays-that pay tribute to an author even more vivid than his books.. Writer Pat Conroy died three years ago this month, on March 4, 2016. His absence, still grieved by many admirers, offers at least one consolation. With Conroy gone, perhaps the discussion of his legacy can eventually focus a little less on the man, a bit more on the books he left behind. They include his small body of memoirs and the best-selling novels "The Great Santini," "The Prince of Tides" and "Beach Music," each one shaped by his tragic past.

title: EBay Plans Strategic Review of Assets
summary: Review includes classifieds group and StubHub, and it comes as company announces pact with activists. EBay Inc. will review the company's operations and assets and add two directors to its board, with a third new member to be added later in 2019, as the company has entered into agreements with affiliates of activist investors Elliott Management Corp. and Starboard Value LP.

title: Manhattan Loft Gardens Aims to Transform East London
summary: Harry Handelsman's new hotel and apartment block opens in Stratford. It is about aspiration, not just accommodation," says Harry Handelsman of his new hospitality venture, Manhattan Loft Gardens, in Stratford, East London's former Olympic district. Handelsman, 69, is the CEO of the Manhattan Loft Corporation, known for reviving unprepossessing areas of London via its elegantly refurbished buildings-such as the Chiltern Firehouse hotel, which rejuvenated the formerly staid Marylebone. But this latest project is more than a skyline-transforming, 145-room hotel (The Stratford, opening in May) and apartment block with a destination restaurant, three sky gardens, sleek interiors by Space Copenhagen and Studio KO and daily yoga programs. It's a social experiment. "I want to create a community," says Handelsman. There are 248 apartments on the upper floors-from light-filled studios to three-bedroom penthouses-which are currently available as weekly, monthly or extended accommodation options inspired by the New York long-stay hotel scene of the '60s and '70s. Handelsman hopes to attract a young creative crowd who will interact with each other and the hotel guests, perhaps in the ground floor's open-kitchen brasserie or around a firepit in the 25th-floor garden. "I know I have an amazing building," he says, "but it's the people who will make it exciting." thestratford.com

title: In the Interest of Time, LOOGYs May Get Left Out
summary: Among the proposals under discussion is a new rule that would require relievers to face a minimum of three batters or finish an inning. This would make the left-handed specialist an endangered species.. Baseball commissioner Rob Manfred wants games to move faster, and he appears willing to consider just about any radical idea to make that happen. Even if it means killing off an entire species of player.

title: The Side Effects of Million-Dollar Drugs
summary: Gene therapies will bring hope for patients and opportunity for investors-as long as someone is willing to pay for them. It's only a matter of time until the first million-dollar drug arrives in a deeply dysfunctional health-care system. With the new drugs come painful questions: Who is stuck with the bill, do they have the cash to pay it and how can they avoid the obligation?

title: How Two Duke Benchwarmers and a 3-D Printer Rescued a Top NFL Prospect
summary: When Daniel Jones fractured his collarbone, the medical staff turned to two walk-ons to custom build a brace for the star player and help him return to the field. Indianapolis

title: Hot ETF Play of 2019 Is Betting on Home Loans
summary: Mortgage fund provides a happy medium when it comes to duration. Mortgages are suddenly hot with investors.

title: A Tuppence Might Feed the Birds, but Can It Pay Off a Home Loan?
summary: Mary Poppins sequel suggests a small investment would save a family house, but even a magical nanny needs more.

title: Washington Gov. Jay Inslee Enters 2020 Presidential Race
summary: Campaign will be centered on climate change. WASHINGTON-Washington state Gov. Jay Inslee said Friday he will seek the Democratic presidential nomination with a campaign focused on addressing climate change.

title: Medicare for All Loses Momentum Among Democrats
summary: Public support dips amid questions about costs. Democratic support for Medicare for All is slipping from the high levels seen around the November midterm elections as voters worry about its price tag and the toll it would take on both private and employer health coverage.

title: GE CEO Letters Decoded: Shrinking Ambitions, Disappearing Buzzwords
summary: A look at how Larry Culp's first shareholder missive compares with ones written by Jeff Immelt and John Flannery. Larry Culp's first shareholder letter as General Electric Co.'s CEO was relatively brief and deployed less frequently some words and phrases that longtime leader Jeff Immelt often used to define the goals of the once-sprawling conglomerate.

title: Where the Jobs Are
summary: A look at the 10 hottest and coldest labor markets in the U.S.. To determine the overall hottest and coldest labor markets, The Wall Street Journal looked at the 53 metro areas with more than 1 million people. The Journal's ranking is based on five attributes: average unemployment rate in 2018; labor-force participation rate in 2018; the change in the average monthly employment and labor-force levels in 2018 from a year earlier; and the change in average weekly wage in the first half of 2018 from the first half 2017, reflecting the latest available wage data. The area with the highest average ranking among the five categories was determined to be the hottest labor market. Moody's Analytics provided the analysis of Labor Department data necessary for this report.

title: Embattled WPP's Shares Leap but Ad Gloom Lingers
summary: Ad giant's quarterly sales fall but by less than analysts expected. Shares in WPP PLC jumped 8% Friday after the advertising giant reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter results and said its performance should improve toward the end of 2019.

title: Death of A380 Superjumbo Opens New Battleground
summary: Airbus can now fight Boeing's 777X with a stretched version of its popular A350. The demise of the A380, the largest commercial liner ever built, has left a superjumbo-sized hole in the aircraft market. Investors can expect a race to fill it.

title: Don't Tell Tottenham Fans: For Spurs' Future, Look to Arsenal's Past
summary: As the club waits to move into a new stadium, there is plenty to learn from a North London rival. LONDON-Back when Tottenham Hotspur's shiny new stadium was still just a set of 3-D renderings, the club made a pointed announcement about one spec of its future home. It wasn't the lounge with a view into the players' tunnel, or the in-house micro-brewery that could deliver 10,000 pints a minute.

title: Inside the Hottest Job Market in Half a Century
summary: Resume Subscription. The job market doesn't get much better than this. The U.S. economy has added jobs for 100 consecutive months. Unemployment recently touched its lowest level in 49 years. Workers are so scarce that, in many parts of the country, low-skill jobs are being handed out to pretty much anyone willing to take them-and high-skilled workers are in even shorter supply.

title: Five Takeaways From Powell's Congressional Testimony
summary: The Fed chairman's appearance on Capitol Hill went smoothly, with little pushback from lawmakers. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell completed two days of testimony on Capitol Hill this week. Here are five things learned from the exchanges with lawmakers.

title: Following the Tourist Trail to Macau Looks Like the Best Bet
summary: Gambling revenue growth has stalled in the semiautonomous Chinese city, but casinos more geared to the mass market could still do well. High rollers are leaving Macau but tourists are streaming in. That's making an unlucky start to the year for the gambling hub not so bad after all.

title: Female Factor: Women Drive the Labor-Force Comeback
summary: The share of women participating in the workforce is rising much faster than for men. The gender gap that pervades so much of worklife also is shaping the U.S. labor pool's recent rebound, only this time it is women who are driving most of the gains.

title: After Years of Decline, American Manufacturing Jobs Are Making a Comeback
summary: Manufacturing employment has risen for 18 straight months, the longest stretch of gains among nonsupervisory roles since the mid-1990s. America's factories are hiring again.

title: Left Behind in a Nationwide Jobs Recovery: Charleston, W.Va.
summary: Thanks to its dependence on coal, the state lacks the educated workforce and thriving cities to prosper in today's economy. Charleston, W.Va.-In a booming U.S. jobs market, this city of less than 50,000 is struggling to keep up.

title: In This Oil Town, Even the Barber Can Make $180,000
summary: One of America's hottest labor markets is in West Texas, where the brisket is scarce, the 'man-camps' are full, and oil workers with no time to spare pay $75 to skip the line at the barber shop.. West Texas has seen its share of oil booms, but the people there say this one is unlike any they've seen.

title: How Do You Stack Up in Today's Job Market?
summary: Put in your info to see if you're one of the many workers benefiting from a strong U.S. labor market. Are you one of the many American workers benefiting from today's strong labor market? We collected data on more than 500 occupations and analyzed them by age, education, and location. Enter your information, and we'll tell you if you're coming out ahead for each category you select.

title: Pompeo Pledges to Defend Philippine Forces in South China Sea
summary: Philippines shelves planned review of military alliance after U.S. assurances. MANILA, Philippines-The Philippines shelved a planned review of its military alliance with the U.S. in return for a verbal commitment that American forces would defend the country's vessels in the South China Sea, removing a major irritant between the longstanding partners.

title: Chinese Shares Gain Global Sway Thanks to Index Firm's Move
summary: MSCI is quadrupling the contribution of stocks listed in Shanghai and Shenzhen in a key index. SHANGHAI-Index provider MSCI Inc. said it would more than quadruple the contribution of mainland Chinese shares to an influential global benchmark, a move that will make shares in Shanghai and Shenzhen much more important to global investors.

title: China's Stock Market Isn't Quite The Bargain It Seems
summary: The Chinese shares many active fund managers prefer suffer from an attractiveness deficit.. Many investors say Chinese stocks are inexpensive, despite this year's surge. That is true on a marketwide basis. But the stocks many active fund managers prefer-those linked to the Chinese consumer or the technology sector-aren't quite so appealing.

title: Versum Materials Rejects Bid From Germany's Merck
summary: Company says it plans to stick with all-stock merger with Entegris. Versum Materials Inc. on Friday said its board rejected an unsolicited takeover proposal by German pharmaceutical and chemical company Merck KGaA and said it plans to stick with its all-stock merger with Entegris Inc.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: HBO CEO Resigning Amid AT&T Restructuring
summary: Richard Plepler of HBO said it is time to go after nearly three decades at channel; Turner President David Levy is also resigning. Two longtime executives of the entertainment empire that AT&T Inc. bought for more than $80 billion are stepping down, as the telecommunications giant gets ready to put its stamp on WarnerMedia days after the last antitrust hurdle to the deal was cleared.

title: U.S., North Korea Trade Blame for Failed Summit
summary: Collapse of talks in Hanoi leaves an uncertain path, though both Washington and Pyongyang indicated they weren't shutting the door to dialogue. HANOI-A summit that might have led to North Korea's first tangible disarmament steps faltered because Pyongyang wouldn't freeze all of its weapons programs and sought billions of dollars in sanctions relief, a senior State Department official said Friday, as the two sides blamed each other for their failure to reach an agreement.

title: Tesla Shifts to Online Sales Model
summary: Car maker starts taking orders for $35,000 version of Model 3. Tesla Inc. said it would begin shutting stores and move to selling vehicles only over the internet, an extraordinary step aimed at cutting costs so the company can offer its Model 3 compact at a long-awaited starting price of $35,000.

title: Financier Who Amassed Insurance Firms Diverted $2 Billion Into His Private Empire
summary: Resume Subscription. Soon after Greg Lindberg moved into the insurance business, the North Carolina entrepreneur went on a spending spree.

title: Fed Chief Says U.S. Economy 'Is in a Good Place'
summary: Central-bank chairman cites patience in determining future rate changes; Europe, China pose growth risks. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said the U.S. economy is doing well, but he highlighted recent risks to growth that prompted the central bank to signal it is done raising interest rates for now.

title: Southwest Files Lawsuit Against Mechanics Union
summary: Airline accuses workers of stepped-up effort to take planes out of service to gain an edge in contract talks. The dispute between Southwest Airlines and its mechanics union escalated on Thursday as the carrier filed a lawsuit accusing the workers of reporting trivial maintenance issues in an effort to take planes out of service and gain an advantage in contract negotiations.

title: SpaceX Prepares Capsule for Humans
summary: Demonstration flight scheduled for Saturday won't include crew but will test hardware reliability. From the same Florida launchpad that blasted the first humans to the moon, NASA on Saturday will attempt a feat it hasn't tried since the space shuttles were retired in 2011: send into orbit a spacecraft designed to transport astronauts.

title: Boom Town, U.S.A.
summary: A gusher of crude production has transformed the Permian Basin into America's hottest oilfield, turning what was a remote corner of the country into a prosperous boom town, seemingly overnight.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: China's Stock Market Isn't Too Big to Ignore
summary: MSCI is raising the portion of China A-shares in its EM index. That doesn't give investors carte blanche to snap them up.. MSCI has decided to quadruple the weighting of Chinese stocks included in its flagship Emerging Markets Index. Investors shouldn't take this as an invitation to pile into China without thinking.

title: U.N. Hits Stalemate Over Venezuela Diplomatic Efforts
summary: Russia and China veto U.S. resolution, saying its call for elections threatens nation's sovereignty. UNITED NATIONS-The U.S. clashed with Russia and China at the U.N. Security Council on Thursday, reflecting a larger global split over how the international community should respond to Venezuela's political and economic crisis.

title: Kraft Heinz Says Probe Delayed Financial Report
summary: Food maker's procurement department investigated internally and by securities regulators. Kraft Heinz Co. said Thursday it would be late in filing its annual report with securities regulators as it concludes an internal investigation into its procurement department.

title: Dell Technologies Quarterly Results Beat Projects
summary: Dell returned to the public markets in December. Dell Technologies Inc.'s results in the latest period beat Wall Street targets but forecast sales growth to slow down this year.

title: Nigeria's Democracy Survives
summary: Saturday's election was far from perfect, but it's still good news.. There's enough going wrong in Africa that it's easy to miss the positive developments. Nigeria's presidential election on Saturday is one of them, even if it was imperfect.

title: The Scary Side of Tesla's Big Reveal
summary: Tesla's Model 3 sedan for $35,000 raises unsettling issues about its finances and customer demand. Tesla finally has achieved a longstanding corporate goal. Its investors, however, should hold their applause.

title: Albany Debates Revenue Forecasts as Budget Talks Heat Up
summary: Legislative leaders say the outlook isn't as bad as Cuomo projects, estimating almost $1 billion in revenue above the governor's figures. New York's budget picture isn't as bad as Gov. Andrew Cuomo projects, leaders of the state Legislature said Thursday.

title: Dow Slips but Holds Onto Healthy 2019 Gains
summary: The Dow ended February with its best two-month start to a year since 1987. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 closed out February with their best two-month start to a year in roughly three decades, despite ending the month with three sessions of slight declines.

title: Thank You, Tax Reform
summary: Kevin Hassett was right about growth in 2018. Larry Summers wasn't..

title: Boomtown for Hoaxers
summary: A Michigan man is accused of burning down his own home.. Oh look, another alleged hate-crime hoax. News broke this week that Nikki Joly, a transgender gay-rights activist in Jackson, Mich., has been charged with burning down his own home, seemingly for the purpose of presenting himself as the victim of anti-gay savagery.

title: New York Governor Appeals to Amazon to Reconsider
summary: No signs that the tech company is rethinking its decision to scuttle its plans for a New York City headquarters. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo said Thursday that he has been in contact with Amazon.com Inc. executives, urging them to rethink their decision to abandon plans for a headquarters campus in Queens.
